A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.

A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.

Let $R$ and $R'$ be rings. A map $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a ring homomorphism if it satisfies two conditions: (i) $\varphi(a+b)=\varphi(a)+\varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$, making $\varphi$ a group homomorphism with respect to addition, and (ii) $\varphi(a \cdot b)=\varphi(a) \cdot \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$ and $\varphi(1)=1$, making $\varphi$ a monoid homomorphism with respect to multiplication.

An integral domain $R$ is called a Euclidean domain if it admits a map $\delta: R-\{0\} \longrightarrow \mathbb{N}$ making possible Euclidean division in $R$ in the following sense: Given elements $f, g \in R, g \neq 0$, there are elements $q, r \in R$ such that $f=q g+r$, where $\delta(r)<\delta(g)$ or $r=0$.
An A-module M is said to be finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators. It is also referred to as a finite A-module.

The minimal polynomial of an element \\(\alpha\\) in a field extension is the monic polynomial of lowest degree in the base field that has \\(\alpha\\) as a root. It is a prime polynomial and generates the kernel of the evaluation homomorphism from the polynomial ring of the base field to the field generated by \\(\alpha\\). 
(Alt.2)
Let $K \subset L$ be a field extension and $\alpha \in L$ an element that is algebraic over $K$. The unique monic polynomial $f \in K[X]$ of smallest degree such that $f(\alpha)=0$ is called the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$ over $K$.

An element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ if it satisfies any of the equivalent conditions: (i) there exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]$, (ii) the subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated, (iii) viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M$.

A normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. It is a prestage to Galois extensions. An algebraic field extension \\(K \subset L\\) is called normal if it satisfies the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4: (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.

Let $G$ be a group and $X$ a set. An action or an operation of $G$ on $X$ is a map $G \times X \longrightarrow X, \quad(g, x) \longmapsto g \cdot x$ such that: (i) $1 \cdot x=x$ for the unit element $1 \in G$ and for elements $x \in X$. (ii) $(g h) \cdot x=g \cdot(h \cdot x)$ for $g, h \in G, x \in X$.
Two cycles $(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$ and $(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s})$ are called disjoint if the sets $\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$ and $\{y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s}\}$ have no elements in common.
A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A Commutative Ring (ID: 2) is a specialization of a Ring (ID: 1) because it fulfills all the properties of a Ring with the additional property that its multiplication is commutative.
A Euclidean domain (ID: 4) is a specialization of a Ring (ID: 1) because it fulfills all the properties of a Ring and additionally admits a Euclidean division.
A group action is a map.
